messages: a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (22:24): Darn, anne caught up with me in the lastweek poll
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:25): Am I still on zero?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:25): Yeah
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (22:29): I'm still on 2. And one of those votes was mine.
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (22:29): I'm obviously not much of a smeghead
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (22:32): You're probably too productive
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (22:32): You need to be all talk, like me
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:35): breaks shelly's blog
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:35): i hate xml
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:43): i'm amused at rob burns' comments on shelly's blog
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:44): he claims that rdfa would hurt google
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:45): when the whole point is that rdf doesn't help anyone on the scale of the web, because of the spam problem
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:45): it can only work on a local scale as far as i can tell
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (22:46): The trust tools will save us
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (22:49): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, which one is Shelly's blog?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (22:50): ah, this one http://realtech.burningbird.net/semantic-web/semantic-markup/stop-justifying-rdfa

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:50): discovers that he can use WebKit in his OpenGL game by being really dumb and just rendering everything to a bitmap surface and uploading as a texture on every frame, and it actually works surprisingly well
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:50): and HTML+CSS+JS seems a better GUI development language than the custom library the game currently uses
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:50): If you are giving a name as Surname, First Name where does a Jr. Suffix go?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (22:52): It comes after the name in any case
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:52): k
0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17 (22:52): I thought shelley powers was a "she", no?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:52): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: http://www.google.com/search?q=%22smith+john+jr%22+OR+%22smith+jr+john%22
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:52): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: which seems to indicate nobody has made up their mind about which way round it goes
0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17 (22:53): bwah, and I misread 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e completely
0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17 (22:53): I guess I've gone contextually blind, and missed "rob burns"
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:55): Is it bad I have a Makefile to turn my dissertation from LaTeX to PDF?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:56): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: No
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (22:56): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: People who don't think don't qualify for having "made up their mind" ;)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:56): Good.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:56): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: In my experience it's very common to have a Makefile for that kind of thing
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:56): It also replaces [WC] with a rough word-count
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:56): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: though my experience is limited to a group of about three people
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:56): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Did they per-chance learn about LaTeX from each-other?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (22:57): I have a five-line script that just deletes all output and runs the four necessary commands
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (22:57): It's completely and utterly bogus that the default still requires several incantations to do one simple thing
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:57): grumbles as the list of reasons for having to define "xml parser", of all things, in the html5 spec grows

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:58): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: They probably started using LaTeX before meeting each other, so they learned by copying random examples from web sites until it looked right
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:58): (or at least that's what I did)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:58): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: It seems to be what most people do.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (22:59): When it comes to latex, I'm convinced 2 > 5
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:59): :D
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:00): I say we burn a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 for saying that.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (23:00): looks for an example
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (23:00): Oh, actually it has an OMakefile rather than a Makefile
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:01): Issue: wc returns a lot of whitespace too
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (23:01): but it's the same idea, and it just does some gnuplot and xfig conversions, and runs bibtex and then runs pdflatex three times
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:01): Solution: grep -Eo [^[:space:]]+
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (23:02): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: By "a lot of whitespace" do you mean "one newline at the end"?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:02): 767
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:02): I.e., it has leading whitespcae
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:02): *whitespace
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (23:03): Not when I run it
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (23:03): miktex had this wonderful command that would run tex and bibtex and everything else as many times as it needed to
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (23:03): echo 'hello world'|wc -w|hexdump -c
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (23:04): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: I tend to use Kile now, which does all that stuff automatically too
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (23:04): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: Your computer is crazy
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:04): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Certainly.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (23:05): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: Anyway, you could do sed 's/ //g' which would be much easier to type than [^[:space:]]+ :-)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:05): dude, g, we don't burn people for disagreeing with us
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:05): we listen to them and see whether they have any good reasons for disagreeing
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:06): and if they do we adopt them
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:06): that way they agree with us again
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:06): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: But I don't have to type it because it is in the makefile, and it only deals with 0020
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:06): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: s/g a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554/g dangnamit!
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:06): blames BenMillard
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:06): (Or, alternatively, BenMilliard)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:07): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: But it's a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9!
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:07): "g" is either to type than "g<tab>"
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (23:07): I'm the shared 5th most smegheaddy person here!
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:07): easier even
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:07): either is apparently easier to type than easier
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:07): headdesks
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:08): But "g" isn't highlighted in my IRC client, and I can't highlight every case of the letter g.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:08): i know
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:08): that's what makes it awesome
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:08): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: So you give me a valid reason to ignore you? :P
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:10): oh when i want you to pay attention i'll hit the tab key, don't worry :-P

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:11): apparently the guy who wrote http://stackoverflow.com/questions/432933/will-html-5-validation-be-worth-the-candle#434044 missed teh part where we take out everything from the spec that browsers don't implement
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:12): What's this with something creating files starting with ._?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:12): Apple puts its resource forks in ._ files, iirc
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:13): Ah, OS X on a non-HFS+ FS
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (23:13): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: OCamlMakefile creates temporary directories like ._bcdi, but it seems unlikely to be that
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:14): Also: Anyone know anyway to get Windows to hide POSIX hidden files (i.e., .*)?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (23:15): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554, enable the NTFS hidden flag for those files
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:15): On a FAT32 FS?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (23:15): and make sure you do the crazy thing and have hidden files not shown in windows explorer
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:15): FAT has a Hidden flag that does the same thing
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (23:15): FAT32 also has a hidden flag, doesn't it?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:16): has had since before you were born, g :-P
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:16): :P
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (23:16): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554, why are you using a FAT32 FS on a windows machine?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:16): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: Because FAT32 is the only FS that actually works everywhere?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (23:16): "why are you using a windows machine" ftfy (</reddit>)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:17): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: Because I don't really want to take my laptop into school all the time, so I'm stuck with the Windows boxes there :P
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (23:17): ok. If you need the disk to be read directly by multiple systems, rather than just having it in the windows machine permanently and access it over network
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:17): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: It's a USB memory stick :P
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:17): Currently mounted at /Volumes/GSNEDDERS
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:18): :P
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:18): (therefore, not /Volumes/G)
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (23:19): wonders how long it will take for a superior file system to replace FAT32 as the defacto standard on USB drives
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (23:21): heads off
